covered: Valid Request: Happy path and many valid query-parameter combinations (offset/limit, audit) are covered (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05).
Empty Response: Empty-result cases are tested (TC06, TC24) and pagination edge cases that return empty arrays (TC07, TC08).
Pagination: Offset/limit behavior, limit=0, offset greater than total, very large offsets/limits and large-data performance are present (TC02, TC07, TC08, TC19, TC26).
Query Parameters: Valid and invalid values for offset, limit and audit are exercised, including extra/unexpected parameters (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05, TC11, TC12, TC18).
Authorization: Missing and invalid authentication token scenarios are included (TC13, TC14).
Error handling: Client errors (malformed searchKey, invalid params), server errors, dependency failures and timeouts are covered (TC09, TC10, TC11, TC12, TC15, TC16, TC25).
Security: Injection attempt is explicitly tested (TC17).
Performance & Concurrency: High-volume and concurrent-request scenarios are present (TC19, TC20).
Behavioral/regression checks: Backward compatibility and partial-db population scenarios are present (TC21, TC23).
gaps: Default parameter behavior: There is no explicit assertion that omitted optional query parameters use the documented defaults (offset default 0, limit default 100, audit default NONE). TC01 implicitly covers “no query params” but does not validate limit/offset/audit default values or that results are truncated to the default limit.

Bundle schema / field-level validation: Tests do not validate the Bundle object structure or required fields against the API definition (field types, required fields, nested audit fields beyond presence).
Caching behavior: No scenarios checking caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or behavior for conditional GETs.
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests for rate limiting responses (e.g., 429) or behavior under burst traffic aside from concurrent correctness.
Authorization nuance: No tests for forbidden access (403) or role-based access control if applicable (only unauthenticated/invalid token -> 401 are covered).

Response headers and content-negotiation: Apart from one check for application/json (TC01), there are no assertions for other relevant headers (Content-Length, pagination-related headers if any) or behavior when Accept header differs.

Negative/edge numeric bounds: No tests for upper bound validation when service enforces maximum allowable limit smaller than client-specified value (e.g., attempting limit > service max resulting in 4xx or forced truncation).
Internationalization / encoding: No tests validating handling of unicode/URL-encoded searchKey or path-encoding edge cases (although malformed and injection cases exist).

Storage-consistency race conditions: While concurrency correctness is checked for read consistency, there are no tests for simultaneous write operations affecting search results (if relevant for consistency guarantees).
recommendations: Add explicit tests asserting documented default parameter behavior: verify offset defaults to 0, limit defaults to 100, and audit defaults to NONE when omitted; confirm result count respects the default limit.
Add schema-level assertions for Bundle objects: validate required fields, types, nested audit details (when audit=FULL/MINIMAL/NONE), and that malformed/missing fields are not present or flagged.
Introduce caching tests: check for ETag / Cache-Control / Last-Modified headers and conditional GET behavior (304 responses) to verify caching semantics.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts or repeated requests to verify 429 or backoff behavior and document acceptable limits.
Cover authorization nuances: include tests for 403 forbidden (role/permission-based failures) if the API has RBAC or scope differences, and test token expiry scenarios.
Test response headers and content-negotiation more comprehensively: verify Content-Type, Content-Length, any pagination headers, and behavior when Accept header requests other media types.
Add tests for upper-bound numeric validation: attempts to request limits beyond service-enforced maximum should be exercised and expectations documented (error vs truncation).
Add encoding/URL-encoding tests for searchKey: verify unicode, percent-encoding, and long-path handling to ensure robust path param parsing.
If relevant, add tests that combine reads with concurrent writes to exercise data-consistency guarantees for search during mutations.
